Excess Risk Calculation: Additional infections/deaths  among households that are attributable to a vaccination visit/adult visit to a health facility, that  would not have occurred during the course of the epidemic if not for vaccination/adult visit to a health facility.

Methodology adapted and expanded from:  Abbas K. et al.  2020.  Benefit-risk analysis of health benefits of routine childhood immunisation against the excess risk of SARS-CoV-2 infections during the COVID-19 pandemic in Africa.  The Lancet Global Health doi: 10.1016/S2214-109X(20)30308-9
Variable
Unnamed: 3: Comment

Excess Risk Calculation: Number of children receiving vaccination/adults receiving health intervention x
Unnamed: 3: This is just for illustration, the actual number of visits and infections is calculated separately for each intervention

Excess Risk Calculation: Number of visits for vaccination/health intervention x
Current percentage of population that has or has had COVID
Unnamed: 3: Number of COVID cases in 2020 divided by total population

Excess Risk Calculation: Duration of period at risk (in months):  Number of months until herd immunity is achieved
Unnamed: 3: Length of community spread. After this period, between 40% and 70% of the population will have been infected (corresponds to herd immunity required for R0 between 1.6 and 3.6

Excess Risk Calculation: Proportion of SARS-CoV2 infected population at end of risk period
Unnamed: 3: Herd immunity calculated based on R0:

Excess Risk Calculation: Reproduction number for SARS-CoV2
Unnamed: 3: Expected number of cases directly generated by one case in a population where all individuals are susceptible to infection

Excess Risk Calculation: Duration of infectiousness (day)
Unnamed: 3: Number of days an infected individual spreads the virus on average

Excess Risk Calculation: Risk ratio of health care provider being infected and infectious vs. another community member
Unnamed: 3:
Higher risk of being infected (between 1 and 4 times) because of higher frequency of exposure to other people
Community member:  6 contacts per day
Vaccinator: 21 potentially infectious contacts per day

Excess Risk Calculation: Risk ratio potentially infectious contact of a health care provider transmitting vs. another community member
Unnamed: 3: Lower risk of onward transmission (between 0.25 and 1 times) because most of HCW's contacts with vaccinees are brief, and they have enhanced risk awareness and use corresponding protective measures including basic respiratory hygiene and personal protective equipment as available

Excess Risk Calculation: Increased risk of inpatient stay vs. ambulatory visit (1 day stay vs. 1 outpatient visit)
Unnamed: 3: Higher risk of getting infected  due to a) longer stay in a potentially contagious environment, b) contacts with more health care providers,

Excess Risk Calculation: Average number of transmission-relevant contacts of a community member per day
Number of non-health care provider contacts of child and carer during their travel to the vaccine clinic and in the waiting room
Prevalence among community members on any given day (ΘΨ / T)
Unnamed: 3: Assumes reasonably flat epidemic curve, total cases spread out over months of community spread as specified above

Excess Risk Calculation: Prevalence among health care provider on any given day ( l1xpo)
Unnamed: 3: Higher risk due to increased number of potentially infectious contacts

Excess Risk Calculation: Probability of transmission given potentially infectious contact with community members (R0/NΨ)
Unnamed: 3: General risk of acquiring infection in the community

Excess Risk Calculation: Probability of transmission given potentially infectious contact with health care provider (l2 x t0)
Probability of transmission given potentially infectious contact with health care provider(s) during hospital stay (l2 x h x t0)
Unnamed: 3: Risk of acquiring infection  interacting with health care provider(s) during hospital stay

Excess Risk Calculation: Effectiveness of Health Facility Mitigation Measures
Effectiveness of Personal Protective Equipment
Unnamed: 3: Reduction in transmission risk across all interventions

Excess Risk Calculation: Effectiveness of Temperature Screening
Unnamed: 3: Reduction in transmission risk across all interventions

Excess Risk Calculation: Effectiveness of  Reducing Number of Contacts
Unnamed: 3: Proportional to Reduction (intervention-specific), see Sheet 6. Cells EX7:HS7

Excess Risk Calculation: 1. Infection Risk for vaccination visits (child + caretaker):
Probability for a SARS-CoV-2 infection for the whole household of a child who gets vaccinated
Unnamed: 3: One minus the probability of either the infant or the mother not being infected by either the vaccinator or anyone else on any of the vaccination visits

Excess Risk Calculation: Probability for excess SARS-CoV-2 infection for the whole household of a child who gets vaccinated (Px (1-Θ))
Unnamed: 3: Probability of facility-visit related infection x Percent of population who has not gotten infected at the end of the risk period

Unnamed: 3: 1 - (1 - po to)2vn

Excess Risk Calculation: Probability of transmission during contact with health care provider
Unnamed: 3: 1 - (1 - pv tv)2vn

Excess Risk Calculation: Probability of transmission if clinic uses PPE
Unnamed: 3: P = 1 - (1 - pv tv x (1 - Eppe))2v

Excess Risk Calculation: Probability of transmission if clinic uses PPE and temperature screening
Unnamed: 3: P = 1 - (1 - pv tv x (1 - Eppe) )2v x (1 - Ets)

Excess Risk Calculation: 2. Infection Risk for adult visits:
Probability for a SARS-CoV-2 infection for the whole household of an adult seeking care
Unnamed: 3: One minus the probability of the adult not being infected by either the health care provider or anyone else on the visit or visits to the health facility

Unnamed: 3: 1 - (1 - pv tv)vn

Excess Risk Calculation: Probability of transmission if clinic uses PPE and temperature screening
Unnamed: 3: P = 1 - (1 - pv tv x (1 - Eppe) )v x (1 - Ets)

Excess Risk Calculation: 3. Infection Risk for hospitalization visits:
Probability for a SARS-CoV-2 infection for the whole household of an adult seeking care
Unnamed: 3: One minus the probability of the adult not being infected by either health care providers or anyone else during the hospital stay

Unnamed: 3: P = 1 - (1 - pv th x (1 - Eppe) )v x (1 - Ets)
